case_name: K. Simrathmull v. S. Nanjalingiah Gowder

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 8 of 1960 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 8 of 1960.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated January 30, 1956, of the Madras High Court in Special L. Appeal No. 2174 of 1952.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated January 30, 1956, of the Madras High Court in Special L. Appeal No. 2174 of 1952.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on February 28, 1962 by SHAH, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1962. February 28. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SHAH, J.-This is an appeal with special leave against the judgment of the High Court of Madras.

facts.text: On February 18, 1948, S. Nanjalingiah Gowder (plaintiff) borrowed Rs. 1,500/- from K. Simrathmull (defendant).

anchor.surface_text: On February 18,, 1948, S. Nanjalingiah Gowder herein after referred to at the plaintiff-borrowed Rs. 1,500/- from K. Simrathmull-hereinafter called the defendant.

facts.text: On February 19, 1948, the plaintiff executed a sale deed conveying to the defendant certain land at Ootacamund together with a house for Rs. 700/-.

anchor.surface_text: On February 19, 1948 the plaintiff executed a sale deed companyveying to the defendant certain land at Ootacamund together with a house standing thereon and belonging to him for Rs. 700/-.

facts.text: On February 19, 1948, plaintiff executed deed of reconveyance Ext. A-1, counterpart of the sale deed, containing covenant to reconvey if Rs. 1500 paid within two years, pay assessments, taxes, arrears of rent; cancelled if rent arrears for six months.

anchor.surface_text: Two other documents were executed on the same day  1  a deed of reconveyance  Ext. A-1   companynterpart of the sale deed  in favour of the plaintiff which companytained the following companyenant If you pay the sum of Rs. 1500/. within a period of two years 1 shall at your companyt and responsibility execute a sale in respect of Your-mentioned land and house. You shall pay the assessment for the house and the municipal tax, you shall if there is any arrears of rent pay the same, prior to the sale, as per the rental deed executed by you and your father. If there is arrears of rent for six months, the aforesaid companynterpart deed shall become cancelled.

facts.text: On February 19, 1948, Rent Note Ext. B-1 executed by plaintiff and his father Bora Gowder agreeing to pay rent Rs. 26/4/- per mensem for the house and land.

anchor.surface_text: , and  2  a Rent, Note by the plaintiff and his father Bora Gowder in favour of the defendant agreeing to pay rent Ps. 26/4/- per mensem for occupation of the house and the land.

facts.text: Rent accruing due was not paid regularly by the plaintiff and his father, and by April 1949 it was in arrears for seven months.

anchor.surface_text: Rent accruing due was number paid regularly by the plaintiff and his father, and by April 1949 it was in arrears for seven months.

facts.text: On April 20, 1949, plaintiff sent Rs. 52/8/- by postal money order for rent of two months, but it was not accepted by the defendant.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff sent Rs. 52/8 - by postal money order being rent for two months, on April 20, 1949, but it was number accepted by the defendant.

facts.text: Plaintiff filed suit on November 7, 1949 in the Court of the Subordinate Judge, Ootacamund for specific performance of the agreement of reconveyance in Ext. A-1.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff then filed on November 7, 1949 a suit in the Court of the Subordinate Judge, Ootacamund for specific performance of the agreement of reconveyance companytained in the deed Ext. A-

facts.text: Trial Court (Subordinate Judge) dismissed the suit holding conditions in Ext. A-1 not strictly complied with, agreement cancelled.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was dismissed, for, in the view of the trial Court, the companyditions incorporated in Ext. A-1 had number been strictly companyplied with, and the agreement stood cancelled.

facts.text: Decree of trial Court affirmed in appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The decree of the trial Court was affirmed in appeal

facts.text: Madras High Court in second appeal reversed the decree and ordered specific performance.

anchor.surface_text: But in second appeal the High Court of Madras reversed the decree and ordered specific performance.

facts.text: Sale deed, deed of reconveyance Ext. A-1 and Rent Note Ext. B-1 were parts of the same transaction.

anchor.surface_text: The sale deed. the deed of reconveyance Ext. A-1 and the Rent Note Ext. B-1 were undoubtedly parts of the same transaction.

facts.text: Plaintiff pleaded that sale deed constituted mortgage by conditional sale, but inadmissible as separate documents.

anchor.surface_text: The plea of the plaintiff that the sale deed Ext. A-1 companystituted a transaction of mortgage by companyditional sale is inadmissible, because the sale deed and the companyenant for reconveyance are companytained in separate documents.

facts.text: Plaintiff did not comply with terms of agreement for reconveyance, as found by trial court and confirmed by appellate courts.

anchor.surface_text: Indisputably, on the findings of the trial Court and companyfirmed by the Appellate Courts, the plaintiff has number companyplied with the terms of the agreement for reconveyance.

facts.text: First condition for reconveyance (within two years) fulfilled, but second (rent not in arrears >6 months) not fulfilled when demanding specific performance.

anchor.surface_text: When the plaintiff demanded specific performance .of the agreement of reconveyance, the first companydition was fulfilled but the second was number.

facts.text: Property worth Rs. 15,000/- on date of institution of suit (Nov 1949).

anchor.surface_text: Even on the defendants case it was on the date of the institution of the suit worth Rs. 15000/-.

facts.text: Defendant purchased property about a year and seven months prior to suit institution for Rs. 1500/-.

anchor.surface_text: The defendant purchased it only about a year and seven months prior to the date of the institution of the suit for Rs. 1500/-.

facts.text: Supreme Court set aside High Court decree and restored trial court decree.

anchor.surface_text: The decree passed by the High Court must therefore be set aside and the decree passed by the trial Court restored.

facts.text: Plaintiff debarred from proving transaction was mortgage due to s.58(c) Transfer of Property Act.

anchor.surface_text: It is unfortunate, having regard to the provision of s. 58 c  of the Transfer of Property Act, that the plaintiff is debarred from proving that  ,he transaction was in the nature of a mortgage.

facts.text: Defendant appears to have overreached the plaintiff and taken sale deed when mere loan on security intended.

anchor.surface_text: He appears to have overreached the plaintiff and taken a document of sale A.1 R.  1950  C. 38.  2   1930  39 E.R 195. companyveying the property when a mere loan was intended on the security of the property.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that equity relieves against penalties when the intention of the penalty is to secure payment of a sum of money or attainment of some other object, and when the event upon which the penalty is made payable can be adequately compensated by payment of interest or otherwise. Thus relief is granted in equity against the penalty in a money bond...

concepts.interpretation: Applies to secure payment of money compensable by interest; cited Halsbury vol 14 p620 Art 1147; illustrations in Kilmer and Devendra Prasad cases.

concepts.unlisted_description: Relief where penalty secures monetary payment compensable otherwise

anchor.surface_text: But there is a well recognised exception to this rule which is enunciated in Halsburys Laws of England Vol. 14 TIT Edition page 622 paragraph 1151, as follows Where under a contract, conveyance, or will a beneficial right is to arise upon the performance by the beneficiary of some act in a stated manner, or at a stated time, the act must be performed accordingly...

concepts.interpretation: No relief against breach where beneficial right conditional on act in stated manner/time, absent fraud/accident/surprise; Halsbury para 1151.

concepts.unlisted_description: Exception to penalty relief for conditional beneficial rights

anchor.surface_text: The Federal Court in Shanmugam Pillai and others v. Annalakshmi Ammal and others held by a majority of three to two that where under an agreement an option to a vendor is reserved for repurchasing the property sold by him the option is in the nature of a concession or privilege and may be exercised on strict fulfillment of the conditions...

concepts.interpretation: Repurchase option is concession/privilege; strict compliance required; no specific enforcement on failure; refusal not penalty; accepted by Supreme Court following Shanmugam Pillai and Davis v. Thomas.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: enalty in a money bond, and also against penal sums made payable on breach of bonds, companyenants and agreements for payment of money by installments

concepts.unlisted_description: Vendor's option to repurchase requires punctual strict compliance with conditions

issues.text: Whether the sale deed Ext. A-1 constituted a transaction of mortgage by conditional sale?

anchor.surface_text: The plea of the plaintiff that the sale deed Ext. A-1 constituted a transaction of mortgage by conditional sale is inadmissible, because the sale deed and the covenant for reconveyance are contained in separate documents.

issues.text: Whether the court could relieve the plaintiff against forfeiture of rights under the reconveyance agreement in exercise of equitable jurisdiction despite failure to strictly comply with conditions?

anchor.surface_text: Indisputably, on the findings of the trial Court and confirmed by the Appellate Courts, the plaintiff has not complied with the terms of the agreement for reconveyance. The plaintiff, however submitted that the court could relieve him against the forfeiture of his rights in exercise of the courts equitable jurisdiction. The defendant submitted that the covenant for reconveyance was in the nature of a concession granted by the defendant subject to certain conditions and if the conditions were not fulfilled the right could not be enforced.

anchor.surface_text: The plea of the plaintiff that the sale deed Ext. A-1 constituted a transaction of mortgage by conditional sale is inadmissible, because the sale deed and the covenant for reconveyance are contained in separate documents.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that equity relieves against penalties when the intention of the penalty is to secure payment of a sum of money or attainment of some other object, and when the event upon which the penalty is made payable can be adequately compensated by payment of interest or otherwise.

arguments.claim: Exception to equity relief: beneficial right arising on performance of act in stated manner/time requires strict compliance, absent fraud/accident/surprise

arguments.claim: Repurchase option to vendor is concession/privilege exercisable only on strict fulfillment of conditions; failure leads to loss of right, no specific enforcement; not a penalty

anchor.surface_text: The Federal Court in Shanmugam Pillai and others v. Annalakshmi Ammal and others held by a majority of three to two that where under an agreement an option to a vendor is reserved for repurchasing the property sold by him the option is in the nature of a concession or privilege and may be exercised on strict fulfillment of the conditions...

arguments.court_reasoning: we accept the view of the majority enunciated in Shanmugam Pillais case

holdings.text: The plea of the plaintiff that the sale deed Ext. A-1 constituted a transaction of mortgage by conditional sale is inadmissible, because the sale deed and the covenant for reconveyance are contained in separate documents.

anchor.surface_text: The plea of the plaintiff that the sale deed Ext. A-1 companystituted a transaction of mortgage by companyditional sale is inadmissible, because the sale deed and the companyenant for reconveyance are companytained in separate documents.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Separate documents for sale and reconveyance covenant make plea inadmissible under s.58(c) Transfer of Property Act.

holdings.text: The court has no jurisdiction to relieve the plaintiff against the extinction of the right to demand reconveyance due to failure to strictly comply with the conditions of the deed.

anchor.surface_text: On this question the trial Judge with whom the First Appellate Court agreed held that the companyrt had numberjurisdiction to relieve against the extinction of the right to demand reconveyance, because the plaintiff had failed to companyply strictly with the companyditions of the deed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Trial and first appellate courts correctly held no equitable relief available for non-strict compliance; Supreme Court endorses.

holdings.text: Equity does not relieve against breach where a beneficial right arises upon performance of an act in a stated manner or at a stated time; strict compliance required absent fraud, accident or surprise.

anchor.surface_text: But there is a well recognised exception to this rule which is enunciated in Halsburys Laws of England Vol. 14 TIT Edition page 622 paragraph 1151, as follows Where under a companytract, companyveyance, or will a beneficial right is to arise upon the performance by the beneficiary of some act in a stated manner, or at a stated time, the act must be performed accordingly...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies well-recognised exception from Halsbury to deny relief against forfeiture of conditional beneficial right.

holdings.text: An option to repurchase property reserved to the vendor is a concession or privilege exercisable only on strict fulfillment of conditions; failure to comply punctually results in loss of right, no specific enforcement, and refusal is not enforcement of penalty.

anchor.surface_text: The Federal Court in Shanmugam Pillai and others v. Annalakshmi Ammal and others 1  held by a majority of three to two that where under an agreement an option to a vendor is reserved for repurchasing the property sold by him the option is in the nature of a companycession or privilege and may be exercised on strict fulfillment of the companyditions...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Accepts majority view in Shanmugam Pillai case and Davis v. Thomas; applies to facts where rent arrears condition breached.

holdings.text: We accept the view of the majority enunciated in Shanmugam Pillais case.

anchor.surface_text: We accept the view of the majority enunciated in Shanmugam Pillais case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explicit adoption of binding precedent on strict compliance for vendor repurchase options.

holdings.text: The decree passed by the High Court must therefore be set aside and the decree passed by the trial Court restored.

anchor.surface_text: The decree passed by the High Court must therefore be set aside and the decree passed by the trial Court restored.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of legal principles to facts requires reversal of High Court granting specific performance.

holdings.text: Having regard to s.58(c) of the Transfer of Property Act, the plaintiff is debarred from proving that the transaction was in the nature of a mortgage.

anchor.surface_text: It is unfortunate, having regard to the provision of s. 58 c  of the Transfer of Property Act, that the plaintiff is debarred from proving that  ,he transaction was in the nature of a mortgage.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Observes statutory bar reinforces inadmissibility of mortgage plea.

anchor.surface_text: But there is a well recognised exception to this rule which is enunciated in Halsburys Laws of England Vol. 14 TIT Edition page 622 paragraph 1151, as follows Where under a companytract, companyveyance, or will a beneficial right is to arise upon the performance by the beneficiary of some act in a stated manner, or at a stated time, the act must be performed accordingly...
